question: Do you hear that? That noise. Excuse me. What is that sound? No, it's different. It's not the engines. It's getting louder. Um...okay. No! Yeah..
answer: You okay, honey?

question: Yeah, Mom. I'm fine.
answer: Alright. Better get cooking or you'll be late for school.

question: Jacob! You're too old to run away from home! Payback time...
answer: No!

question: Don't worry, I have a strong stomach.
answer: I dreamed you away before I was born! Mom said you couldn't come back!

question: What's going on?
answer: Free speech. The right of assembly.

question: What is this place?
answer: It's a home. A foster home. For teenagers. It's where you go when things get bad. It's the place to figure out what to do next. It's a home for kids that no one else wants. It's MY home.

question: Nothing...YET.
answer: Lighten up, mister.

question: And what gutter did you crawl out from, kid? We don't want your kind here.
answer: My kind? What kind is that?

question: Drug addicts. Dope pushers. We have stand up and take charge.
answer: Swell. I've just got a couple of questions for you...Do you love your parents?

question: Of course I do...
answer: Are they alive?

question: My mother is.
answer: What's it like?

question: What's it like?
answer: Assholes.

question: I can think of a stronger word. Are you okay?
answer: Yeah. Thanks. I'm Karen.

question: Jacob.
answer: Are YOU okay?

question: Yeah. I just haven't had much to eat lately.
answer: Then come help me unpack. I guess the sandwich is alright, huh?

question: It's incredible. Best I've ever had.
answer: You're not from around here, are you?

question: No. I've been on the road for a couple of days.
answer: Do you need a place to stay?

question: My father died before I was born. My mother, she's dead, too.
answer: You have a legal guardian?

question: No.
answer: Been in any state or federal program?

question: Okay. You got three, maybe four days to rest up while we try and find a more permanent arrangement for you. But his isn't going to be a free ride. We're part of a community summer work project and eighty percent of the money you make goes to the house. Everybody works - and that includes you. Are you on drugs?
answer: No.

question: Good. If I catch anything stronger then an aspirin on you, you're outta here. No arguments. You got that straight?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Hey, beautiful. How's it going?
answer: Hi, Scott.

question: Who's Barney Rubble?
answer: This is Jacob Johnson. He's a new resident. At least temporarily.

question: He better not be rooming with me. I value my privacy.
answer: No, I believe that honor goes to Wesley.

question: No. I'm fine. Thanks.
answer: Come on. Let's hop to it. Gotta make way for those new indoor tennis courts. The fate of the world lies in the balance. Okay, this load's full.

question: Yeah, no problem.
answer: I don't know. Maybe you should think about switching to de-caf or something.

question: She doesn't like to be touched.
answer: No shit!

question: Don't take it personally. It's not her fault.
answer: What happened to her?

question: Her mother was a hooker. She forced Gina to carry on the tradition. When she was thirteen...
answer: Jesus.

question: You look terrible.
answer: Thanks.

question: I'm sorry...I just wish you'd tell me what happened to you, that's all.
answer: I can't talk about it right now. I'll tell you later. I promise.

question: Okay. Why don't you sit and rest for a bit. The supervisor's not around. You look like you could use it.
answer: I think I will. What! Jesus fucking...Oh, shit! Huh? What's going on?

question: I think I will. What! Jesus fucking...Oh, shit! Huh? What's going on?
answer: Aren't you going to bed?

question: I'm not tired.
answer: Bullshit. If you looked any more tired, you'd be dead.

question: That's right.
answer: You gotta sleep, man.

question: Why? Who says? You know, people don't even really know why we sleep. They haven't found any physical reason for it.
answer: But they do know that you go nuts if you don't.

question: Sharks don't sleep. They can't pump water through their gills on their own. They have to always keep moving. If they stop, they can't breath. If they go to sleep, they die.
answer: You're not a shark.

question: I'm not sure. I think I'm some kind of carrier. He's somehow inside me and as soon as I fall deep enough into sleep he'll be let loose. You guys were great to take me in. I just don't want to thank you by getting you all killed.
answer: Okay. Show me Springwood.

question: That's what I've been trying to tell you.
answer: There's NEVER been a town there.

question: That's how YOU see it. I was part of the nightmare, so I'm the only one who notices the difference.
answer: Look, Jacob. You don't have to convince us that nightmares are real. Everybody in this room has been through one. And some of us are still living it. But the thing is, we know it's just in our heads now. It can be just as bad as the real thing was, but it's still only a memory. It can't hurt us physically, unless we do the hurting ourselves.

question: You don't believe me, either, do you?
answer: I don't know.

question: Why are you still here?
answer: I'm not sure. I guess, I guess I see a lot of me in you.

question: Feels good to see someone more fucked up than yourself, huh?
answer: Yeah. That must be it.

question: But you haven't told me why you're here at this place.
answer: I can't talk about it right now. Maybe later. Do you want me to stay with you?

question: Yeah, that'd be great. Don't let me sleep, okay?
answer: I'll do my best.

question: Yeah. Thank God.
answer: Where are you going?

question: I'm leaving.
answer: Why?

question: He can't hurt you if I'm gone. Maybe I'll go to the desert or something. I'll lie down in the middle of nowhere and finally get some sleep. Krueger can feed of the dreams of snakes and vultures.
answer: Fine. You're just going to take off then...

question: Don't do this to me. I'm just trying to protect you and the others.
answer: Right. You blow into town and then blow right out. Terrific.

question: I don't understand why you're so mad at me.
answer: You just don't get it, do you?

question: Get what?
answer: Running away doesn't help.

question: And you're going to convince me, huh?
answer: Maybe.

question: Don't fucking put me under! You'll set him free!
answer: Every town as an Elm Street! Thanks for the lift, kid!

question: What do you want from me?
answer: I already got it! The rest I'm going to get from your new little friends.

question: Leave them alone!
answer: It's my duty to clean up the neighborhood!

question: What have you done with my town?
answer: Aw, poor baby's homesick, isn't he? Don't worry. We'll all be one happy family soon. Wanna be the first recruit?

question: Over my dead body!
answer: As you wish.

question: What's going on?
answer: Just relax, everything's fine.

question: That's what you say...
answer: You're lucky you're here instead of juvenile hall. You put up quite a fight. But you're clean. No traces of drugs or alcohol in your blood.

question: I could've told you that.
answer: Hold on there.

question: You said I was fine. I have to get back. My friends are in trouble.
answer: I said you weren't on drugs, but I never said you were fine. You're suffering from extreme fatigue and stress that manifested itself into one hell of an anxiety attack. At least that's what we hope it is. You had a major seizure, Jacob.

question: You don't understand. This whole town is in danger.
answer: We're keeping you here for observation. You're not going anywhere tonight.

question: You can't do that. You don't have the right!
answer: Yes we do. Your temporary guardian, Mr. Ross, signed all the papers. If you're okay in the morning we might let you go home. Until then, you're bed bound.

question: But...
answer: We took off the restraints. Do you want us to put them back on?

question: moves to the couch, clearly mesmerized by the scene. He curls up, absently pulling the white blanket around him as he watches: vaguely tenses at this and absently pulls the blanket more tightly around him to compensate, like a cocoon. Fuck this. Dad?
answer: Yeah, Wesley. Everything's gonna be great! Just have a smoke on us! Didn't Daddy ever tell you what the Surgeon General says...?

question: Go to hell!
answer: Right...

question: When I was put under, Freddy was released. I know this because I dreamed it.
answer: And that dream was real?

question: Yes. Wesley was his first victim.
answer: Aw, man...

question: Thank you. There's more. There are... other people in there. In the nightmares.
answer: Like him?

question: No. Different. There are three of them. They're dressed in black. They have powers like Freddy, but they seem to be on our side.
answer: Who are they?

question: They're kids that Freddy killed years ago. THEY don't even know how they got there. But they're somehow patrolling dreamworld to put a stop to Krueger.
answer: Then why haven't these guys done the job already?

question: They say they need help. I don't know what or why...yet.
answer: I can tell you who needs help.

question: Hey, I'm trying to save all of us.
answer: I won't believe it until I see it.

question: By then it'll be too late. It was too late for Wesley.
answer: They're going to use all this to shut us down.

question: I know. It's my fault.
answer: You going to try to run away again?

question: It's too late for that. I have to stay and try and put a stop to it.
answer: I'm sorry. It's all so hard to accept.

question: I wish I could convince you of the danger you and the others are in.
answer: I've been in danger before. THAT I can handle.

question: This is worse than anything you can imagine.
answer: I wouldn't be so sure about that. Come on. Let's go inside. She was great. Loving. Supportive, caring - everything a mom should be. Except she had one fatal flow

question: I'm sorry.
answer: I know nightmares are real, Jacob. I know.

question: So did my mom. She taught me a lot about dreams.
answer: Like what?

question: She told me that a lot of people have special dream powers. I inherited some from her - and some I have all to myself. She showed me how I could link up with other people's dreams - to actually be inside with them.
answer: That sounds wonderful. But...I don't know...

question: A little hard to imagine, huh?
answer: Yeah. I'm sorry.

question: I can convince you.
answer: How?

question: Easy. We're doing it now.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I mean we're dreaming. You and me. Together.
answer: I don't believe it.

question: It's true. We're really doing it.
answer: But what if I'm just dreaming of you telling me that?

question: We'll compare notes when we wake up. Then you'll know.
answer: Did you bring us here on purpose? Can you go anywhere you want?

question: Sometimes. It's not as easy as linking up, though.
answer: Wow, I never knew...

question: Show off.
answer: When things get bad it helps to be someone else. I use it to protect myself.

question: I think I like you the way you always are.
answer: Look!

question: Karen, no!
answer: Oh no...

question: Come on!
answer: What?

question: You heard me. I said wake up!
answer: How? This is my old house. How did I get here?

question: I think I get it now. You hit me.
answer: Are you hurt?

question: Um...no.
answer: If he had done it, you'd be dead.

question: You better get back to your room. We don't want anybody to get the wrong idea.
answer: Or the right one?

question: Get out of here.
answer: That's something else my mom taught me.

question: Okay, everybody. Out. Jacob and I are going to have a little talk. Now.
answer: I'm sorry, but...

question: Hey, I don't know what kind of shit you're shoveling to these kids, but it's going to stop. My Good Samaritan instincts have their limits. We've had enough tragedy around this place. We don't need you making things worse with fantasies.
answer: You don't understand

question: And I want you to stay away from Karen.
answer: It's a free country.

question: This isn't America, it's my house. I've been checking up on you. You have no record with the police or the state or any of the runaway groups. You're the invisible kid. And if I sense even a little bit more trouble-making from you, you're going to vanish from here. Got it?
answer: Yes, sir. You're supposed to be off-limits to me.

question: Yes, sir. You're supposed to be off-limits to me.
answer: It's okay. The Ross's have gone to a council meeting and Scott's in his room. We should be safe for awhile.

question: Wonderful.
answer: Jacob, what are we going to do?

question: I'm going to go to bed soon.
answer: Now you WANT to sleep?

question: I have to find the Dream Police. I think I'm somehow their link to all this. They only seem to appear when I'm around. You woke me up before I had a chance to talk to them last night.
answer: I'm sorry. I was scared.

question: your fault. I have to ask them what we're supposed to do to help them. And maybe I can protect Gina while I'm in there.
answer: What about Scott?

question: He's on his own.
answer: Oh...

question: I don't mean to be cold,but we've done everything to convince him. Gina's too scared to understand. I think Freddy will go after her next.
answer: What should I do?

question: You have to stay awake.
answer: That's not going to be easy. I'm half asleep already.

question: You have to try.
answer: I'd better get out of here.

question: Okay. Be careful.
answer: YOU be careful. I'm not going anywhere.

question: Jacob, we need you to bring the rest together.
answer: The rest? You mean the kids at the home?

question: Yes. We need as many of you as we can get. And you must bring them to Springwood.
answer: How?

question: No. They're taking you away. They say it's for your own good.
answer: They can't do that.

question: Yes, they can. They consider Mary and I possibly unfit to act as foster parents. They're going to find temporary homes for you until this mess is straightened out. I'm so very sorry.
answer: No, please.

question: You'll talk to the police about that. Don't worry. We'll all try and work this out.
answer: Will we be able to go back to the Ross's?

question: I don't know. You'll have a place to stay in the mean time.
answer: Will we be together?

question: If it's still here.
answer: Jacob, what are we going to do?

question: Nothing.
answer: What do you mean, nothing?

question: How can you do this?
answer: Do what? I'm not doing anything.

question: Exactly. After all we've been through you just throw in the towel. Why?
answer: Because we're fucked. The last thing the Dream Police told me was that they needed all our help. Together. Even if we weren't about to be split up there aren't enough of us left to make a difference.

question: How do you know that?
answer: I don't. But, it's all just too much. I've tried so hard and nothing's worked. I'm spent. I'm wasted. I'm...I'm so tired.

question: So you're just going to give up? I'll bet that's something your mother never taught you.
answer: And we're not going to waste it.

question: Look, I don't know what's going on anymore. Two of my friends die and now you tell me I have to drop into dreamland with you guys to do battle with the dude that did it.
answer: We'll have help.

question: Ah, yes. I almost forgot. The Sleepy Squad. Alright. I'll make you a deal. I told you I wouldn't believe this stuff unless I saw it. If I understand this correctly, all I have to do is fall asleep and you just whisk me into the action.
answer: Right.

question: Okay. If that happens, if both of you show up in my dream, I'll help you out. If nothing happens, then I'll get a good night's sleep and laugh at you in the morning.
answer: Fine. You got a deal. And you won't be disappointed.

question: Into the wild black yonder. Freddy Krueger. Yeah, right. Years ago some sicko gets fried and now he comes back to stick it to you when you're snoozing. Stupid bedtime story. Oh, this is lovely. Yeah, what? Um, well, let me see...
answer: Scott! You're here.

question: Yeah. Fun town. Talk to any of the neighbors, yet? They're a swell bunch of folks.
answer: Uh-huh. Real friendly, too.

question: So this is a dream?
answer: And I'm in it with you. Convinced?

question: Maybe I'm just dreaming bout being here with you. Wouldn't be the first time.
answer: Nope. I tired that one already. Doesn't work. Come on, we have to find Jacob. Jacob! Thank God!

question: Ah, that's okay. I think I'm underage, anyway. No, really. I'm driving. That's okay. I'll just sit at the bar. You bet. You'll be the first to know. Um, a beer, I guess. And that's all?
answer: Welcome to my favorite haunt.

question: So you're the man.
answer: At your service.

question: What's on your mind?
answer: A deal.

question: A deal's what got me into this.
answer: Bring Jacob to me.

question: What's in it for me?
answer: Power. You don't need to hang out with those losers. You're a take-charge kind of guy, Scott. Like when you took charge of your father.

question: Leave my father out of this.
answer: I'll make you mayor of Rosedale.

question: After you make it look like this?
answer: You can have Karen.

question: Alive?
answer: Any way you want her.

question: Okay.
answer: Shake?

question: No time. You guys find Karen!
answer: No more... Jacob! You scared the shit out of me!

question: The feeling is mutual.
answer: Where are the Dream Police?

question: I told them to look for you. What are you doing here? Don't you know what this place is?
answer: I do now. Look what I found.

question: You've got to get out of here.
answer: Wait. You have to see this.

question: You don't understand. The Police can't kill Freddy. They literally chopped each other to pieces and he's still alive! Now I'm supposed to figure out how to get rid of him.
answer: But I think I found the answer. Shut up for a second and look at these.

question: Okay, so he's a bad artist.
answer: No! You told me Krueger's mother committed suicide and no one knows who his father was, right?

question: Yeah...
answer: Freddy's been pushing all our buttons with our pasts. These are HIS past. Don't you get it? HE was a foster child, too!

question: But in reality Freddy hasn't lived here for decades.
answer: Like you tried to tell me once before, this is a dream. Who knows why this is all here.

question: All evils from all times in history...
answer: And isn't this where it all started in Springwood? On Elm Street?

question: But what does this do for us?
answer: There's got to be a way to use it against him.
